elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0010">
<ce:simple-para id="fspara0010" view="all">(a) View of the coordination environments of Zn(II) ions in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. All hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (a) –<ce:italic>x</ce:italic> + 1, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, –<ce:italic>z</ce:italic> + 5/2; (b) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic> + 1/2, –<ce:italic>y</ce:italic> + 1/2, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic> + 1/2; (c) –<ce:italic>x</ce:italic> + 1/2, –<ce:italic>y</ce:italic> + 1/2, –<ce:italic>z</ce:italic> + 2; (d) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, –<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic> − 1/2; (e) –<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, –<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, –<ce:italic>z</ce:italic> + 2. (b) The dinuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] unit. (c) The 3D framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. (d) Schematic representation of the (3,4,6)-connected topological network for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 1

(a) View of the coordination environments of Zn(II) ions in 1. All hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (a) –x + 1, y, –z + 5/2; (b) x + 1/2, –y + 1/2, z + 1/2; (c) –x + 1/2, –y + 1/2, –z + 2; (d) x, –y, z − 1/2; (e) –x, –y, –z + 2. (b) The dinuclear [Zn2(datrz)2] unit. (c) The 3D framework of 1. (d) Schematic representation of the (3,4,6)-connected topological network for 1.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0015">
<ce:simple-para id="fspara0015" view="all">(a) View of the coordination environments of Zn(II) ions in 2. All hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (a) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, –<ce:italic>y</ce:italic> + 1, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (b) –<ce:italic>x</ce:italic> − 1, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, –<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (c) –<ce:italic>x</ce:italic> − 1, –<ce:italic>y</ce:italic> + 1, –<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>; (d) –<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, –<ce:italic>z</ce:italic> + 1; (e) –<ce:italic>x</ce:italic> − 1/2, –<ce:italic>y</ce:italic> + 1/2, –<ce:italic>z</ce:italic> + 1; (f) <ce:italic>x</ce:italic> + 1/2, –<ce:italic>y</ce:italic> + 1/2, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>. (b) Paddle wheel shaped dinuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] unit. (c) The dinuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] unit. (d) The 3D framework of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. (d) Schematic representation of the (4,6)-connected topological network for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 2

(a) View of the coordination environments of Zn(II) ions in 2. All hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. Symmetry codes: (a) x, –y + 1, z; (b) –x − 1, y, –z; (c) –x − 1, –y + 1, –z; (d) –x, y, –z + 1; (e) –x − 1/2, –y + 1/2, –z + 1; (f) x + 1/2, –y + 1/2, z. (b) Paddle wheel shaped dinuclear [Zn2(COO)4] unit. (c) The dinuclear [Zn2(datrz)2] unit. (d) The 3D framework of 2. (d) Schematic representation of the (4,6)-connected topological network for 2.

Fig. 3

The PXRD patterns (a) for compound 1 and (b) for compound 2. The TG curves (c) for compound 1 and (d) for compound 2.

<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0025">
<ce:simple-para id="fspara0025" view="all">(a) The luminescent emission spectra for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in the solid state at room temperature. (b) The luminescent emission spectra of free ligands (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>bpt, H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bptc and Hdatrz).</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 4

(a) The luminescent emission spectra for compounds 1 and 2 in the solid state at room temperature. (b) The luminescent emission spectra of free ligands (H3bpt, H4bptc and Hdatrz).

elements.clean_text:
Abstract
Two new Zn(II) compounds, namely [(CH3)2NH2]2n[Zn3(bpt)2(datrz)2]n (1) and [(CH3)2NH2)]n[Zn2(bptc)(datrz)]n·n(H2O) (2) (H3bpt = biphenyl-3,4′,5-tricarboxylic acid, H4bptc = biphenyl-3,3′,5,5′-tetracarboxylic acid, Hdatrz = 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole), have been obtained by the self-assemble reactions of Zn(NO3)2, 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole, aromatic polycarboxylate ligands under solvothermal conditions. Single crystal X-ray structural analyses reveal that both compounds display three-dimensional (3D) frameworks. Compound 1 features a trinodal (3, 4, 6)-connected topological network with the point symbol of {4.62}2{4.64.8}{46.64.85}. Compound 2 displays a binodal (4, 6)-connected topological network with the point symbol of {32.62.72}{34.42.64.75}. In addition, the thermal stabilities and luminescent properties of compounds 1 and 2 were also investigated in the solid state at room temperature.

</ce:simple-para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Organic carboxylate tuned two different Zn(II) compounds.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">These two compounds feature two distinct topologies.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">These two compounds exhibit intense luminescence at room temperature.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sectitle0030">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Over the past few decades, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been extensively studied for their intriguing topological frameworks and huge potential applications as functional materials in the realm of luminescence, catalysis, magnetism and gas separation . One common method for the construction of MOFs is the hydrothermal or solvothermal self-assembly of metal ions and organic ligands. Through this method, numerous MOFs have been successfully obtained and structurally characterized . However, it is still a great challenge in crystal engineering to obtain the MOFs with predictable frameworks and properties. It is well known that the structures and properties of MOFs greatly depend on the structure of the organic ligands, the coordination geometry and electronic characteristics of the metal ions . Thus, selection of appropriate organic ligands and metal ions are the most important for the construction of desired MOFs with potential properties. In addition, the synthetic strategy is also a key factor for the design and construction of MOFs. Among the widely used strategies for the construction of MOFs, the mixed-ligand self-assemble strategy, which combines the N-containing and O-containing ligands together, has been proven to be one of the most effective methods to synthesize MOFs . The combination of two different kinds of ligands provides more possibilities to result in various 3D structures. 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole (Hdatrz) is a good multidentate N-containing organic ligands which can bridge metal ions in various coordination modes. O-containing polycarboxylate ligands have multiple bonding sites and high affinity to transition metal ions. The combination of polycarboxylate and Hdatrz ligands can result in various intriguing topological frameworks with promising potential properties. To date, only few examples of Zn(II) compounds constructed from Hdatrz and polycarboxylate ligands . Compared with traditional hydrothermal conditions, the solvothermal conditions not only can greatly enhance the solubility of the organic ligands, but also the organic solvents can act as templates directing the synthesis of MOFs. On the basis of aforementioned points, herein, we selected Hdatrz and two different polycarboxylate ligands as the mixed ligands to constructed two new Zn(II) compounds, namely [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2n</ce:inf>[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(bpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bptc)(datrz)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>·n(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>bpt = biphenyl-3,4′,5-tricarboxylic acid, H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bptc = biphenyl-3,3′,5,5′-tetracarboxylic acid, Hdatrz = 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole). Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> features a 3D framework with trinodal (3, 4, 6)-connected topology, and compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> features a 3D framework with binodal (4,6)-connected topology.</ce:para>

Organic carboxylate tuned two different Zn(II) compounds.
These two compounds feature two distinct topologies.
These two compounds exhibit intense luminescence at room temperature.
Introduction
Over the past few decades, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been extensively studied for their intriguing topological frameworks and huge potential applications as functional materials in the realm of luminescence, catalysis, magnetism and gas separation . One common method for the construction of MOFs is the hydrothermal or solvothermal self-assembly of metal ions and organic ligands. Through this method, numerous MOFs have been successfully obtained and structurally characterized . However, it is still a great challenge in crystal engineering to obtain the MOFs with predictable frameworks and properties. It is well known that the structures and properties of MOFs greatly depend on the structure of the organic ligands, the coordination geometry and electronic characteristics of the metal ions . Thus, selection of appropriate organic ligands and metal ions are the most important for the construction of desired MOFs with potential properties. In addition, the synthetic strategy is also a key factor for the design and construction of MOFs. Among the widely used strategies for the construction of MOFs, the mixed-ligand self-assemble strategy, which combines the N-containing and O-containing ligands together, has been proven to be one of the most effective methods to synthesize MOFs . The combination of two different kinds of ligands provides more possibilities to result in various 3D structures. 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole (Hdatrz) is a good multidentate N-containing organic ligands which can bridge metal ions in various coordination modes. O-containing polycarboxylate ligands have multiple bonding sites and high affinity to transition metal ions. The combination of polycarboxylate and Hdatrz ligands can result in various intriguing topological frameworks with promising potential properties. To date, only few examples of Zn(II) compounds constructed from Hdatrz and polycarboxylate ligands . Compared with traditional hydrothermal conditions, the solvothermal conditions not only can greatly enhance the solubility of the organic ligands, but also the organic solvents can act as templates directing the synthesis of MOFs. On the basis of aforementioned points, herein, we selected Hdatrz and two different polycarboxylate ligands as the mixed ligands to constructed two new Zn(II) compounds, namely [(CH3)2NH2]2n[Zn3(bpt)2(datrz)2]n (1) and [(CH3)2NH2)]n[Zn2(bptc)(datrz)]n·n(H2O) (2) (H3bpt = biphenyl-3,4′,5-tricarboxylic acid, H4bptc = biphenyl-3,3′,5,5′-tetracarboxylic acid, Hdatrz = 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole). Compound 1 features a 3D framework with trinodal (3, 4, 6)-connected topology, and compound 2 features a 3D framework with binodal (4,6)-connected topology.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0035">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0040">Materials and instrumentation</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">All reagents and solvents employed in this work were commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were determined with an elemental Vario EL III analyzer. Infrared spectrum using the KBr pellet was measured on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 400–4000 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were recorded on a PANalytical X'Pert Pro powder diffractometer with Cu/Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) with a step size of 0.05°. Thermal analyses were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA–449C thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. Fluorescence spectra of the solid samples were performed on an Edinburgh Analytical instrument FLS920.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental
Materials and instrumentation
All reagents and solvents employed in this work were commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were determined with an elemental Vario EL III analyzer. Infrared spectrum using the KBr pellet was measured on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 400–4000 cm−1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were recorded on a PANalytical X'Pert Pro powder diffractometer with Cu/Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) with a step size of 0.05°. Thermal analyses were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA–449C thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. Fluorescence spectra of the solid samples were performed on an Edinburgh Analytical instrument FLS920.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0045">Synthesis of [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2n</ce:inf>[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(bpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">A mixture of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.030 g, 0.1 mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>bpt (0.025 g, 0.1 mmol), Hdatrz (0.01 g, 0.1 mmol), DMF (3 mL) and CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (1 mL) was placed in a small vial at 90 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature slowly. Colorless block crystals were obtained in 42% yield based on Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. Anal. calcd. for C<ce:inf loc="post">36</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">29</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (1004.88): C, 42.99; H, 2.89; N, 15.33%. Found: C, 42.89; H, 2.85; N, 15.42%. IR (cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3422(w), 1712(m), 1675(s), 1587(m), 1509(m), 1389(m), 1378(m), 1109(w), 1025(w), 958(m), 893(m), 826(m), 778(w), 690(w), 674(w), 589(w), 562(w).</ce:para>

Synthesis of [(CH3)2NH2]2n[Zn3(bpt)2(datrz)2]n (1)
A mixture of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.030 g, 0.1 mmol), H3bpt (0.025 g, 0.1 mmol), Hdatrz (0.01 g, 0.1 mmol), DMF (3 mL) and CH3OH (1 mL) was placed in a small vial at 90 °C for 72 h and then cooled to room temperature slowly. Colorless block crystals were obtained in 42% yield based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Anal. calcd. for C36H29N11O12Zn3 (1004.88): C, 42.99; H, 2.89; N, 15.33%. Found: C, 42.89; H, 2.85; N, 15.42%. IR (cm−1): 3422(w), 1712(m), 1675(s), 1587(m), 1509(m), 1389(m), 1378(m), 1109(w), 1025(w), 958(m), 893(m), 826(m), 778(w), 690(w), 674(w), 589(w), 562(w).

Synthesis of [(CH3)2NH2)]n[Zn2(bptc)(datrz)]n·n(H2O) (2)
The synthesis of compound 2 was similar to that of 1, but with H4bptc (0.093 g, 0.1 mmol) in place of H3bpt. Colorless crystals of 2 were obtained in 38% yield based on Zn(NO3)2·6H2O. Elemental analyses calcd. for C20H18N6O9Zn2 (617.18): C, 38.89; H, 2.92; N, 13.61%. Found: C, 38.86; H, 2.97; N, 13.67%. IR data (KBr pellet): 3450(s), 3179(m), 1652(m), 1626(m), 1550(s), 1478(s), 1431(m), 1182(s), 1135(m), 1034(m), 826(w), 807(m), 787(w), 610(m), 550(m), 519(m), 486(w).

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0055">X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Suitable single crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. Structural measurements were performed with a computer–controlled Oxford Xcalibur E diffractometer with graphite–monochromated Mo–K<ce:italic>α</ce:italic> radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at T = 293(2) K. Absorption corrections were made using the SADABS program . The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full–matrix least–square methods on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> by using the SHELXL–97 program package . All non–hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The H atoms attached to their parent atoms of organic ligands were geometrically placed and refined using a riding model. Crystal data, as well as details of data collection and refinements of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>, selected bond lengths and angles are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>

X-ray crystallography
Suitable single crystals of 1 and 2 were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. Structural measurements were performed with a computer–controlled Oxford Xcalibur E diffractometer with graphite–monochromated Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at T = 293(2) K. Absorption corrections were made using the SADABS program . The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full–matrix least–square methods on F
2 by using the SHELXL–97 program package . All non–hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The H atoms attached to their parent atoms of organic ligands were geometrically placed and refined using a riding model. Crystal data, as well as details of data collection and refinements of 1 and 2 are summarized in

</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/c space group and features a 3D framework with (3,4,6)-connected topology. There are one and a half Zn(II) ions, one bpt<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand, one datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand and one dimethylamine cations. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>a, both Zn1 and Zn2 are four-coordinated with tetrahedral coordination geometries, which are defined by two carboxylate oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms. The Zn–O and Zn–N distances are in the range of 1.914(4)-1.936(3) Å, 1.954(5)-1.994(4) Å, respectively. Two symmetry-related Zn2 ions are bridged by two datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands into a dinuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] unit with the Zn … Zn separation of 3.678 Å (b). These dinuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] units and all Zn1 ions are further connected together <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> the connection of L<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> and datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands, affording a 3D framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (c). In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, each datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand links three Zn(II) ions in <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-N1, N2, N3 mode and each bpt<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand links three Zn(II) ions with its three carboxylate groups in uniform monodentate mode. From a topological viewpoint, each bpt<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand links two dinuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] units and one Zn1 ion, and it can be considered as a 3-connected node. Each Zn1 ion is surrounded by two dinuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] units and two Zn1 ions, and it can be reduced into a 4-connected node. Each dinuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] unit is connected by two Zn1 ions and four bpt<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands, so it can be viewed as 6-connected node. The datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands act as 2-connected spacers. As a result, the 3D framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be simplified into a new trinodal (3,4,6)-connected topological network with the point symbol of {4.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>{4.6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.8}{4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>} (d).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion
Crystal structure of compound 1

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic C2/c space group and features a 3D framework with (3,4,6)-connected topology. There are one and a half Zn(II) ions, one bpt3− ligand, one datrz− ligand and one dimethylamine cations. As shown in 
a, both Zn1 and Zn2 are four-coordinated with tetrahedral coordination geometries, which are defined by two carboxylate oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms. The Zn–O and Zn–N distances are in the range of 1.914(4)-1.936(3) Å, 1.954(5)-1.994(4) Å, respectively. Two symmetry-related Zn2 ions are bridged by two datrz− ligands into a dinuclear [Zn2(datrz)2] unit with the Zn … Zn separation of 3.678 Å (b). These dinuclear [Zn2(datrz)2] units and all Zn1 ions are further connected together via the connection of L3− and datrz− ligands, affording a 3D framework of 1 (c). In 1, each datrz− ligand links three Zn(II) ions in μ
3-N1, N2, N3 mode and each bpt3− ligand links three Zn(II) ions with its three carboxylate groups in uniform monodentate mode. From a topological viewpoint, each bpt3− ligand links two dinuclear [Zn2(datrz)2] units and one Zn1 ion, and it can be considered as a 3-connected node. Each Zn1 ion is surrounded by two dinuclear [Zn2(datrz)2] units and two Zn1 ions, and it can be reduced into a 4-connected node. Each dinuclear [Zn2(datrz)2] unit is connected by two Zn1 ions and four bpt3− ligands, so it can be viewed as 6-connected node. The datrz− ligands act as 2-connected spacers. As a result, the 3D framework of 1 can be simplified into a new trinodal (3,4,6)-connected topological network with the point symbol of {4.62}2{4.64.8}{46.64.85} (d).

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0070">Crystal structure of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in monoclinic <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/m space group and features a 3D framework with (4, 6)-connected topology. The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> contains two halves Zn(II) ions, half of bptc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand, half datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand, half of dimethylamine cation and half of lattice water molecule. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>a, Zn1 is five-coordinated with a square pyramidal geometry, which is defined by four carboxylate oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom. Zn2 is tetrahedrally coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms. The Zn–O and Zn–N distances locate in the range of 1.909(4)-2.071(3) Å, 1.967(3)-2.007(5) Å, respectively. Notably, two symmetry-related Zn1 ions are bridged by four carboxylate groups into a paddle wheel shaped dinuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] unit with the Zn1 … Zn1 separation of 3.012 Å, and two symmetry-related Zn2 ions also are bridged by two datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands into another dinuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] unit with the Zn2 … Zn2 separation of 3.614 Å (b and c). These dinuclear units are further connected together <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> the connection of datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and bptc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligands, generating a 3D anionic framework with the channels occupied by the dimethylamine cations (d). The datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand links three Zn(II) ions in <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-N1, N2, N3 mode, and the bptc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand links six Zn(II) ions with two carboxylate groups in monodentate mode and the other two carboxylate groups in bis-monodentate mode. To better understand this framework of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, topological analysis method was used to simplify the organic ligands and the dinuclear units. Each bptc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand links four dinuclear units, and each dinuclear unit (dinuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] unit or dinuclear [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] unit) is bonded to four bptc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligands and two dinuclear units <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> the connection of datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands. So the bptc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligands and the dinuclear units can be viewed as 4-, 6-connected nodes, respectively, and the datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands can be reduced into linear linkers. Based on this simplification, the whole framework of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be simplified into a bimodal (4, 6)-connected topological network with the point symbol of {3<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.7<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>}{3<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.7<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>} (e).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure of compound 2

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 2 crystallizes in monoclinic C2/m space group and features a 3D framework with (4, 6)-connected topology. The asymmetric unit of 2 contains two halves Zn(II) ions, half of bptc4− ligand, half datrz− ligand, half of dimethylamine cation and half of lattice water molecule. As shown in 
a, Zn1 is five-coordinated with a square pyramidal geometry, which is defined by four carboxylate oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom. Zn2 is tetrahedrally coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms. The Zn–O and Zn–N distances locate in the range of 1.909(4)-2.071(3) Å, 1.967(3)-2.007(5) Å, respectively. Notably, two symmetry-related Zn1 ions are bridged by four carboxylate groups into a paddle wheel shaped dinuclear [Zn2(COO)4] unit with the Zn1 … Zn1 separation of 3.012 Å, and two symmetry-related Zn2 ions also are bridged by two datrz− ligands into another dinuclear [Zn2(datrz)2] unit with the Zn2 … Zn2 separation of 3.614 Å (b and c). These dinuclear units are further connected together via the connection of datrz− and bptc4− ligands, generating a 3D anionic framework with the channels occupied by the dimethylamine cations (d). The datrz− ligand links three Zn(II) ions in μ
3-N1, N2, N3 mode, and the bptc4− ligand links six Zn(II) ions with two carboxylate groups in monodentate mode and the other two carboxylate groups in bis-monodentate mode. To better understand this framework of 2, topological analysis method was used to simplify the organic ligands and the dinuclear units. Each bptc4− ligand links four dinuclear units, and each dinuclear unit (dinuclear [Zn2(COO)4] unit or dinuclear [Zn2(datrz)2] unit) is bonded to four bptc4− ligands and two dinuclear units via the connection of datrz− ligands. So the bptc4− ligands and the dinuclear units can be viewed as 4-, 6-connected nodes, respectively, and the datrz− ligands can be reduced into linear linkers. Based on this simplification, the whole framework of 2 can be simplified into a bimodal (4, 6)-connected topological network with the point symbol of {32.62.72}{34.42.64.75} (e).

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0075">Powder X-ray diffraction patterns and thermal analyses of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The phase purities of bulk samples of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have been confirmed by the powder X-ray diffraction analyses. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>, the major peak positions of the bulk solids of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> match well with those of the simulated patterns based on respective single crystal X-ray diffraction data, indicating that the synthesized compounds are in pure phase. In addition, the thermal behaviors of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were also investigated by thermalgravimetric analysis (TGA) under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere in the temperature range of 30–800 °C. For compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, there is no obvious weight loss in the temperature range of 30–270 °C, and after 270 °C, the framework started to collapse accompanied by the decomposition of the organic components. The residue of the powder may be ZnO (obsd: 24.98%, calcd: 24.18%) (c). For compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the weight loss corresponding to the departure of the lattice water molecule is observed from to (obsd: 2.72%, calcd: 2.92%). The framework can be stable up to 271 °C, where the framework begins to collapse owing to the decomposition of the organic ligands. Finally, the remnants are 27.52%, corresponding to the formation of ZnO (calcd: 26.24%) (d) (see ).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray diffraction patterns and thermal analyses of compounds 1 and 2

The phase purities of bulk samples of compounds 1 and 2 have been confirmed by the powder X-ray diffraction analyses. As shown in 

, the major peak positions of the bulk solids of compounds 1 and 2 match well with those of the simulated patterns based on respective single crystal X-ray diffraction data, indicating that the synthesized compounds are in pure phase. In addition, the thermal behaviors of compounds 1 and 2 were also investigated by thermalgravimetric analysis (TGA) under N2 atmosphere in the temperature range of 30–800 °C. For compound 1, there is no obvious weight loss in the temperature range of 30–270 °C, and after 270 °C, the framework started to collapse accompanied by the decomposition of the organic components. The residue of the powder may be ZnO (obsd: 24.98%, calcd: 24.18%) (c). For compound 2, the weight loss corresponding to the departure of the lattice water molecule is observed from to (obsd: 2.72%, calcd: 2.92%). The framework can be stable up to 271 °C, where the framework begins to collapse owing to the decomposition of the organic ligands. Finally, the remnants are 27.52%, corresponding to the formation of ZnO (calcd: 26.24%) (d) (see ).

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0080">Photoluminescent properties of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Metal-organic frameworks with d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> transition metal ions have attracted intense interest from chemists owing to their potential applications in photochemistry, chemical sensors, and electroluminescent displays . In this work, the luminescent properties of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> as well as the free ligands (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>bpt, H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bptc and Hdatrz) were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. The free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>bpt, H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bptc and Hdatrz ligands display intense emission peaks at 388 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 345 nm), 402 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 345 nm), 435 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 340 nm), respectively, which can be assigned to the <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>*-<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> or <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>*-<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> transitions (b). Under the excitation light of 340 nm, compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> show broad emission bands centered at 442 nm and 445 nm, respectively (a). Notably, the luminescent emission peaks of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are similar to that of free Hdatrz ligand with red-shifts of 7 nm and 10 nm, respectively. The absence of the carboxylate-based ligands (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>bpt and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bptc) emission bands further indicates that the luminescence of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be attributed to Hdatrz intraligand charge transfer .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent properties of compounds 1 and 2

Metal-organic frameworks with d10 transition metal ions have attracted intense interest from chemists owing to their potential applications in photochemistry, chemical sensors, and electroluminescent displays . In this work, the luminescent properties of compounds 1 and 2 as well as the free ligands (H3bpt, H4bptc and Hdatrz) were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. The free H3bpt, H4bptc and Hdatrz ligands display intense emission peaks at 388 nm (λex = 345 nm), 402 nm (λex = 345 nm), 435 nm (λex = 340 nm), respectively, which can be assigned to the π*-n or π*-π transitions (b). Under the excitation light of 340 nm, compounds 1 and 2 show broad emission bands centered at 442 nm and 445 nm, respectively (a). Notably, the luminescent emission peaks of compounds 1 and 2 are similar to that of free Hdatrz ligand with red-shifts of 7 nm and 10 nm, respectively. The absence of the carboxylate-based ligands (H3bpt and H4bptc) emission bands further indicates that the luminescence of compounds 1 and 2 can be attributed to Hdatrz intraligand charge transfer .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sectitle0085">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">In summary, two new luminescent Zn(II) compounds based on 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole mixed with two different aromatic polycarboxylate ligands have been prepared under solvothermal conditions. The two compounds both possess 3D frameworks but with different topologies. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displays a trinodal (3,4,6)-connected topological network, and compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> displays a binodal (4.6)-connected topological network. The high thermal stabilities and intense luminescent properties of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> indicate that they can be used as new photoactive materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion
In summary, two new luminescent Zn(II) compounds based on 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole mixed with two different aromatic polycarboxylate ligands have been prepared under solvothermal conditions. The two compounds both possess 3D frameworks but with different topologies. Compound 1 displays a trinodal (3,4,6)-connected topological network, and compound 2 displays a binodal (4.6)-connected topological network. The high thermal stabilities and intense luminescent properties of compounds 1 and 2 indicate that they can be used as new photoactive materials.

metadata.title: Two new luminescent Zn(II) compounds constructed from guanazole and aromatic polycarboxylate ligands
